Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2013 10:01AM KendraAnn wrote: Hi gtgirl! I just had the procedure done a few days ago, guide wire then excision biopsy. I was scared prior too as well because, well, it sounds unpleasant! But I am happy to tell you it was not painful at all. They numbed my breast first and that was a slight stick and burn and from then on I felt nothing. I also was put under heavy sedation not general anesthesia.. don't remember a thing! Good luck and best wishes!! KendraAnn
Posts.Title: Why do they tell you one thing then it changes at pre-op appt?? gtgirl gtgirl

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2013 09:28AM KendraAnn wrote: While waiting for my biopsy results , I just received my mammo and us report. Does anyone know what this means? Good, Bad, non specific? Thanks! The 1cm x 1 cm is the one that was biopsied. US: There is a 1 cm x 1 cm x 0.3 cm oval mass with a lobulated margin in This is the mammogram report : The tissue of the left breast is heterogeneously dense. This may lower the sensitivity of mammography. The overall pattern and distribution of the glandular tissue is unchanged from the prior exam. There is a 9 mm oval mass with a circumscribed margin in the left breast at 7 o'clock anterior depth. This was present on the prior study and is unchanged. There also is a 1.2 cm oval focal asymmetry with fine calcifications in the left axillary tail. This likely was present on the prior study but is better seen on the current exam.

Posts.Title: Why a second biopsy? KendraAnn KendraAnn

Posts.Content: KendraAnn wrote: Hello, I had a routine mamo a month ago and they found a mass that looked suspicious so they did a ultrasound. Tech, Radiologist and Dr. couldnt decide what it was. They suggested a core biopsy which was performed and came back intraductal papilloma. GREAT!! They sent me to the Breast Surgeon to follow up because I also had 2 other spots in the same breast, but they were 3mm and 9mm, so they weren't concerned about those. So my question is....the surgeon reviewed my ultrasound and mamo and said that the "mass" does not look like an intraductal papilloma and she's concerned they didnt get the right tissue. She stated its larger than she would like (1.2 cm), it is peripheral, and it has something attached to it on one end that looks "jagged". So I'm just wondering what it means when the surgeon doesn't agree with the biopsy? My last mamo was 7 mo ago and these spots were not there, but they did note I have very dense breasts. My surgery is Friday and I'm trying to stay positive, but honetslyI'm a little scared. This is my 2nd scare, I had a lump 8 months ago that luckily was benign:-) Thanks for reading! KendraAnn Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: How could this have possibly happened? KendraAnn KendraAnn

Posts.Content: KendraAnn wrote: I have recently posted another topic which explains my 2nd biopsy, but I do not know how to link them if there is a way. I just went to see my BS for my follow up after excisional biopsy. The good news is path report was papilloma with florid hyperplasia, so benign. Here is the part that I am wondering how and if this could happen..... The lump that the Breast doctor and I felt is not gone. Two days after surgery I felt to make sure it was gone and it wasn't. I thought there must have been an explanation, stroma, lymph node, something. But today when I saw the BS I asked her if she removed the whole lump and she said yes and asked why. I told her I still felt what was the original lump. She felt it and looked at me and said that that's not where the guide wire was put in nor was it where she took the lump from. She said it could be a lymph node that is swollen from the procedure but it could be the lump. She was very kind and did not at all dismiss the fact that this could have been a mistake. She advised I come back to her in 3 months to see if it is a swollen lymph node, if not she'll have to go back in. Three months feels like an eternity. I just can't believe this is even a possibility. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How could this have possibly happened? KendraAnn KendraAnn

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2013 03:53PM KendraAnn wrote: The BS said it feels like a lymph node or the original lump not stroma. I am waiting the 3 months so I hope it does go down. The BS never felt the lump she just went on imaging and the spot where the clip and guide wire were put. I wondered why they needed the guide wire when the lump was VERY palpable by myself and the breast doctor, but I guess I should have asked that question. I've had the lump for 7 months so I know exactly where it was, same spot it is now and it feels the same. When she pointed today to where she took from it was lower and into the breast more. I'll just have to wait. I'm just feeling overwhelmed and needed to talk about it. Thanks for being here for me!
